'''Thomas David Heaton''' (born 15 April 1986) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for English club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
He began his professional career with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] but was unable to break into the first team and spent time on loan with [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]], [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] and [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], before joining Cardiff permanently after his release by Manchester United in July 2010. He then joined [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on a one-year deal with an option of a second year but turned it down in May 2013 in favour of a move to Burnley, whom he has represented in the Premier League, and captained for since 2015.
Formerly an international from under-16 to under-21 level, Heaton has been involved in senior [[England national football team|England]] squads since 2015, finally making his senior debut against [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]] on 27 May 2016 in a [[UEFA Euro 2016]] warm-up fixture.
==Club career== ===Manchester United=== Born in [[Chester]], Cheshire,<ref name=Hugman1011/> Heaton began his football career with [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]], for whom he played both in goal and in midfield, but, after making 20 appearances for the [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] Under-17 team in the previous two seasons, he signed for United as a trainee on 8 July 2002.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He became a regular in the Under-17 team during the 2002–03 season, and picked up an [[FA Youth Cup]] winner's medal despite playing second fiddle to [[Luke Steele (footballer)|Luke Steele]] throughout the entire competition.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He made his first appearance in the reserve team the following season, starting in a 3–1 home win over [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in the Premier Reserve League on 2 October 2003.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} At the end of the 2003–04 season, Heaton was named on the bench for the final of the [[Manchester Senior Cup]] against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], and won a winner's medal despite not taking the field.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
By the 2004–05 season, Heaton had become the first-choice goalkeeper for the Manchester United reserve team, and was named on the bench for [[Stan Ternent]]'s testimonial on 17 August 2004, coming on as a 76th-minute substitute for Luke Steele after Steele had earlier come on for [[Tim Howard]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} With Heaton in goal for 17 of the 28 [[Premier Reserve League]] North matches and 12 of the 22 [[Central League (football)|Central League]] matches, the team went on to win both league titles by nine and five points respectively.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Heaton's form for the reserves resulted in him being loaned out to [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] at the start of the [[2005–06 Swindon Town F.C. season|2005–06]], initially until 1 January 2006.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} During his time at Swindon, he played over 20 matches, saving a penalty on his debut, and was described as "one for the future" by manager [[Iffy Onuora]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He returned to Manchester United,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/player/42250/tom-heaton?season=2006|title=Tom Heaton Player Profile |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> but, after the recall of [[Ritchie Jones]] from [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]], Heaton was sent there for the rest of the season after United rebuffed an approach from [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Heaton spent the [[2007–08 Manchester United F.C. season|2007–08 season]] with the first team-squad at Manchester United, appearing on the bench when [[Edwin van der Sar]] was out due to injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/player/42250/tom-heaton?season=2007|title=Tom Heaton Player Profile |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref>
====Cardiff City (loan)==== At the end of the 2007–08 season, Heaton agreed to move to [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan for the duration of the [[2008–09 Cardiff City F.C. season|2008–09 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff sign Man Utd goalkeeper |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/7407805.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 May 2008 |accessdate=23 May 2008}}</ref> He was chosen as the club's first choice goalkeeper, above [[Peter Enckelman]], for the start of the season by manager [[Dave Jones (footballer, born 1956)|Dave Jones]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Terry |last=Phillips |title=Heaton wins Bluebirds keeper battle for Saints start |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/heaton-wins-bluebirds-keeper-battle-2157149 |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |date=8 August 2008 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He played in every match until late November, with the exception of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] third round tie against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], when he was replaced by Enckelman.<ref>{{cite news |title=Swansea 1–0 Cardiff |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7626773.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=18 February 2009}}</ref> However, late on in Cardiff's 2–1 away defeat to [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] on 22 November 2008, Heaton picked up an injury and was forced off.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} The injury would go on to cost Heaton his place in the team as the club went unbeaten with Enckelman in goal for over two months.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
In February, Enckelman was forced to undergo knee surgery which saw Heaton return in goal on 16 February 2009, when he picked up the [[man of the match]] award in a 4–0 defeat at the hands of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} However, he tore his thigh muscle during the match, ruling him out for up to five weeks.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff rocked by keeper injury |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/7895288.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 February 2009 |accessdate=18 February 2009}}</ref> On his return, Heaton found himself on the bench behind loanee [[Stuart Taylor (footballer, born 1980)|Stuart Taylor]] but, following a 6–0 defeat against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]], he replaced Taylor for the final three matches of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/player/42250/tom-heaton?season=2008|title=Tom Heaton Player Profile |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> However, he was unable to keep Cardiff in the play-off places and he returned to Manchester United at the end of the season.<ref>Phillips, Terry (16 May 2009). [http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-set-offer-skippers-2105918 "Cardiff City set to offer skipper's armband to Roger Johnson"]. ''WalesOnline''. Media Wales. Retrieved 11 April 2017.</ref>
====Queens Park Rangers (loan)==== On 15 August 2009, Heaton was signed by [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on an emergency three-month loan deal, the terms of which allowed him to compete in the [[2009–10 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Exclusive: United keeper pens loan |url=http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10373~1754286,00.html |publisher=Queens Park Rangers F.C. |date=15 August 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306033024/http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10373~1754286%2C00.html |archivedate=6 March 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Heaton's loan spell ended on 8 November 2009.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He made one first-team appearance during his loan, in the 1–0 defeat at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the League Cup on 23 September 2009.<ref name=sb0910/>
====Rochdale (loan)==== After returning from QPR, Heaton joined [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] on 13 November 2009 until the end of December 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title=Heaton makes Dale switch |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11667_5692918,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |date=13 November 2009 |accessdate=13 November 2009}}</ref> He made his debut in a 3–2 loss against [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] on 14 November 2009.<ref name=sb0910/> The loan was then extended until 23 January 2010,<ref>{{cite web |title=Keeping Heaton on |url=http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10441~1917247,00.html |publisher=Rochdale A.F.C. |date=28 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723062351/http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10441~1917247%2C00.html |archivedate=23 July 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> before a further extension pushed the end date back to 31 January.<ref>{{cite web |title=Keeper extends loan |url=http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10441~1944299,00.html |publisher=Rochdale A.F.C. |date=25 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128102446/http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10441~1944299%2C00.html |archivedate=28 January 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> In his 12 appearances for Rochdale, Heaton conceded only ten goals – including four clean sheets – and finished on the losing team just once.<ref name=sb0910/>
====Wycombe Wanderers (loan)==== Heaton spent less than two weeks back at Manchester United before going back out on loan to [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] on 12 February 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wycombe sign keeper Tom Heaton from Manchester United |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wycombe_wanderers/8512842.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 February 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2010}}</ref> He went straight into the Wycombe starting line-up for their away match against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] the following day, which they drew 1–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Brentford 1–1 Wycombe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8494099.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 February 2010 |accessdate=13 February 2010}}</ref> Heaton made his second appearance for the Chairboys in their 0–0 draw against Southampton on Tuesday 23 February 2010.<ref name=sb0910/> He made a great save from a volley to keep the Chairboys on even terms with the Saints.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8497013.stm|title = Wycombe 0–0 Southampton|date = 23 February 2010|accessdate = 4 June 2017}} </ref>
===Return to Cardiff City=== [[File:Tom Heaton.jpg|thumb|upright|Heaton playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2011]]
Meeting with Manchester United manager [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] on his future at the club amidst an expiring contract, Heaton declined an offer to stay at [[Old Trafford]], deciding instead to leave on free transfer in pursuit of regular playing time.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/19/tom-heaton-burnley-england-alex-ferguson |title=Burnley's Tom Heaton: 'It got heated for a minute or two with Alex Ferguson' |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=David |last=Hytner |date=19 August 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Following his release by United, Heaton agreed a deal on 15 June 2010 to return to Cardiff City on 1 July 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd goalkeeper Tom Heaton returns to Cardiff City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8742377.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 June 2010 |accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref> He made his second debut in 4–1 win over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] in the League Cup on 11 August.<ref name=sb1011/> After first-choice goalkeeper [[David Marshall (footballer)|David Marshall]] suffered an elbow injury, Heaton established himself as Cardiff's new number starter.<ref name=sb1011/> In late February, however, he suffered a groin injury, so [[Jason Brown (footballer)|Jason Brown]] and [[Stephen Bywater]] were brought in as cover on loan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn keeper Jason Brown completes Cardiff loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/9412224.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref> Upon his return, Heaton went into the team against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], where they won 4–1, their first win in four matches.<ref>{{cite news |title=Goalkeeper Tom Heaton fitness boost for Cardiff City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/9430040.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2011}}</ref> Heaton's performances during the 2010–11 season earned him the club's Young Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Morris |title=Player of the Year awards. The winners |url=http://www.cardiffcity-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/player_of_the_year_awards_the_winners_673599/index.shtml |work=Cardiff City Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=30 April 2011 |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
Under new manager, [[Malky Mackay]], Heaton found himself as cover for David Marshall, but he played a key part in the club's [[2011–12 Football League Cup|League Cup]] run in which they reached the final thanks to two saves from Heaton in a semi-final [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He suffered an ankle injury just before the final, but he overcame the injury to start at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref name=sb1112/> Heaton followed his penalty heroics against Crystal Palace when he started the penalty shoot-out by pushing [[Steven Gerrard]]'s effort onto the bar, but he ultimately ended up on the losing team as Liverpool won the shoot-out 3–2.<ref name=leaguecup2012>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Cardiff 2–2 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17093419 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Despite the successful cup run, Heaton still found himself second string to Marshall and was released at the end of the season after rejecting a new contract in the Welsh capital.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tom Heaton, Lee Naylor and Paul Quinn leave Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18052140 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
===Bristol City=== In July 2012, Heaton held talks with [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] over a potential move; however, Watford's new owners decided to pull out of the move.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hornets drop Heaton deal |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12691/7870887/Hornets-drop-Heaton-deal |publisher=Sky Sports |date=5 July 2012 |accessdate=5 July 2012}}</ref> Later that month, Heaton went on trial with [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] during their pre-season training camp in Spain and they opened contract talks soon after.<ref>{{cite news |title=City in Heaton talks |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7928823/ |publisher=Sky Sports |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=23 July 2012}}</ref> On 27 July, Heaton signed a one-year deal with the club, with the option for a further 12 months.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bristol City sign ex-Cardiff City goalkeeper Tom Heaton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19013441 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 July 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 18 August 2012, in a 1–0 defeat away to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19221320 "Nott'm Forest 1–0 Bristol City"]. BBC Sport. 18 August 2012. Retrieved 11 April 2017.</ref> A disappointing season in Bristol led to the club owning the worst defensive record in the league with 84 goals allowed, and they were relegated at the end of the season.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Heaton started 43 of Bristol City's 46 matches in the Championship that season, and was viewed as one the club's better players that season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/tom-heaton-great-professional-work-says-sean-o/story-19033783-detail/story.html |title=Tom Heaton was a great professional to work with, says Sean O'Driscoll |newspaper=Bristol Post |date=20 May 2013 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11726/8667370/bristol-city-goalkeeper-tom-heaton-not-ruling-out-staying-at-ashton-gate |title=Bristol City goalkeeper Tom Heaton not ruling out staying at Ashton Gate |publisher=Sky Sports |date=23 April 2013}}</ref>
===Burnley=== [[File:Tom Heaton watches proceedings.jpg|thumb|upright|Heaton playing for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in 2015]]
Heaton joined Burnley in May 2013, after turning down a further one-year deal at Bristol City.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} His decision was to stay in the Championship, and Burnley offered Heaton a two-year contract attaching him to the club until June 2015, with an option of a third year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22569957 |title=Burnley: Bristol City keeper Tom Heaton to join Clarets |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 May 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> A target of manager [[Sean Dyche]] while at Watford, Dyche's first Burnley signing was described as a "good technician" with a "great pedigree".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/dyche-delight-at-heaton-signing-170513-826442.aspx |title=Dyche delight at Heaton signing |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=17 May 2013}}</ref> Heaton immediately became first-choice goalkeeper for Burnley following the departures of [[Lee Grant (footballer, born 1983)|Lee Grant]] and [[Brian Jensen (footballer, born 1975)|Brian Jensen]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He made his Burnley debut against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 3 August 2013.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} On 24 August, he was the recipient of a rare technical caution (his second of the match) for handling the ball after releasing it whilst playing against Brighton, a match they lost 2–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23736888 |title=Brighton 2–0 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Heaton was a part of Burnley's defence that allowed only 37 goals, the fewest in the league, as Burnley returned to the [[Premier League]] for the first time since 2009–10.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Heaton also picked up 19 clean sheets, the most by any keeper in the regular season.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
Heaton made his Premier League debut on 18 August against Chelsea in a 1–3 loss.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/18/burnley-chelsea-premier-league-match-report |title=Cesc Fábregas inspires Chelsea to opening Premier League win at Burnley |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |date=18 August 2014}}</ref> Heaton played in every minute of Burnley's Premier League campaign, the only goalkeeper in the league to do so,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/stats/top/players/mins_played |title=Premier League Player Stats - Minutes Played |work=Premier League |accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> but his efforts would not be enough, as Burnley and their league-worst offense were relegated at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/league-tables/premier-league/19-may-2015/|title=Premier League table after close of play on 19 May 2015|website=11v11.com|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> After the season, Heaton was voted by his teammates as Burnley's Players' Player of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2015/may/clarets-player-of-the-year-awards-2015/ |title=Clarets Player of the Year awards 2015 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=25 May 2015 |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Arsenal Vs Burnley (24108379784).jpg|thumb|upright|Heaton (right) playing for Burnley in 2016]]
On 30 June 2015, Heaton signed a new three-year deal at the club through to the summer of 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Heaton signs new Clarets contract |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/heaton-signs-new-clarets-contract-2514570.aspx |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=30 June 2015}}</ref> Taking over for [[Jason Shackell]], Heaton was named as captain for the [[2015–16 Burnley F.C. season|2015–16 season]], captaining the team for the first time on 8 August 2015, on the opening day of the [[2015–16 Football League Championship|2015–16 Championship season]] against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=United in opening day draw |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/tur6eygqn5lg1prmxswgkfmmd/title/united-in-opening-day-draw |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> Heaton kept 20 clean sheets during the season, second only to [[Dimitrios Konstantopoulos]] of [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxsports.com/soccer/stats?competition=23&season=20150&category=GOALKEEPING&pos=0&team=0&sort=7&sortOrder=0|title=2015-16 English Championship Statistics and Leaders: Goalkeeping|website=foxsports.com|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> as Burnley did not lose in the second half of the Championship season on their way to becoming champions and earning promotion back to the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League]] at their first attempt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=435&teamTabs=results|title=Burnley Results|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36176219|title=Charlton 0–3 Burnley|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 May 2016|accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref> Towards the end of the season, Heaton was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 7|Championship PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=pfateam1516>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36106596 |title=PFA awards: Leicester and Spurs dominate Premier League team |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2016 |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
On 20 July 2016, Heaton signed another new contract, this time a four-year deal running until the summer of 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/2016-17/skipper-heaton-signs-new-four-year-deal-3195783.aspx |title=Skipper Heaton signs new four-year deal |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=20 July 2016}}</ref> On 29 October, Heaton made numerous saves during the match against former club Manchester United, the highlight being a mid-air, fully extended save of [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] that Heaton claimed "nearly broke [his] arm".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2016/10/29/nearly-broke-my-arm-heaton-on-stunning-zlatan-save-day/ |title="Nearly broke my arm" – Heaton on stunning Zlatan save, day |publisher=NBC Sports |first=Nicholas |last=Mendola |date=29 October 2016}}</ref> Afterwards, Heaton required medical attention but remained in the match to lead Burnley to a 0–0 draw, being named Man of the Match in the process.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37737710 |title=Manchester United 0–0 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> In the same season on 22 January 2017, Heaton made his 150th league appearance for the club as he was beaten by a 97th-minute penalty from [[Alexis Sánchez]] that saw Arsenal win 2–1.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/premier-league/2016-2017/live-arsenal-burnley_mtc862208/live.shtml|title=LIVE Arsenal - Burnley - Premier League - 22 January 2017|date=22 January 2017|work=Eurosport|access-date=21 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://us.soccerway.com/matches/2017/01/22/england/premier-league/arsenal-fc/burnley-fc/2241970/?ICID=PL_MS_09|title=Arsenal vs. Burnley - 22 January 2017 - Soccerway|website=us.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=21 March 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Having played for England at various youth levels, Heaton was handed his [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] debut in March 2008 by manager [[Stuart Pearce]] when he replaced [[Joe Hart]] as a substitute during a match against [[Poland national under-21 football team|Poland]].<ref>[http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/footballnation/cardiff-city-fc/2008/06/13/city-new-boy-wants-to-be-number-one-with-united-91466-21067081/ "City new boy wants to be number one with United"]. ''South Wales Echo''. Cardiff. Retrieved 13 June 2008.{{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> However, he did not make the final squad for the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
On 21 May 2015, Heaton was called up to the [[England national football team|England senior team]] for the first time ahead of a friendly against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=England: Jamie Vardy, Charlie Austin & Tom Heaton in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32823264 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Heaton continued to be included in [[Roy Hodgson]]'s squads before finally making his debut as an 87th-minute substitute in place of [[Fraser Forster]] in England's Euro 2016 warm-up match against [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]], played at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]'s [[Stadium of Light]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Tyrone |last=Marshall |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/14522372.Burnley_captain_Tom_Heaton_makes_his_England_debut/ |title=Burnley captain Tom Heaton makes his England debut |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=27 May 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
On 16 May 2018, he was one of 5 players named on standby for the 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
